bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 14, 1929

div1.p: Kean vouches for Harrison and urges Emilie Lawrence Reed to make a donation to Vanderbilt University.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, August 14, 1929
div1.opener:
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
PRESIDENT
SENIOR SURGEON C. H. LAVINDER
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
BRIGADIER GENERAL WM. H. WILMER
MEDICAL RESERVE CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
SECOND VICE-PRESIDENT
CAPT. JAMES C. PRYOR
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES NAVY
EDITOR AND SECRETARY
COL. JEFFERSON R. KEAN
UNITED STATES ARMY, RET.
THIRD VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES R. REYNOLDS
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
FOURTH VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES W. COMFORT, JR.
MEDICAL CORPS, CONNECTICUT NATIONAL GUARD
ASSISTANT EDITOR
MAJOR EDGAR ERSKINE HUME
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE MILITARY SURGEON
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON, D. C.
14 August, 1929
Mrs. Walter Reed,
Blue Ridge Summit, Pa.
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I have a letter from Dr. William Groce Harrison of Birmingham,
Alabama, who has been elected Professor of Medical History at the
Medical School, Vanderbilt University, Tenn. The new Medical Department
has recently received an endowment of ten million dollars, and is going
to establish a department of medical history and a museum. Dr. Harrison
wants some exhibit illustrating the work of your very distinguished husband
in his museum. He would like an autographed letter, especially one written
while he was in Cuba bearing on the work. Dr. Harrison is especially keen
about this on account of his enthusiastic admiration for Walter Reed and
his work. I have met him and know that he is a fine man and in every way
suited for his position. Anything that you can give him for the Vanderbilt
Medical Museum will be well bestowed.

The Irelands and the Keans had a charming visit with you ten days
ago, and all of us enjoyed ourselves very much. We talked with much
pleasure of how well and how happy you looked. We had a lovely trip home
by way of the Valley and the Hagerstown and Frederick road.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. Kean,
J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.,
